#  Generated from FHIR 4.0.1-9346c8cc45, SMART Health IT.

import os
import io
import unittest
import json
from fhirclient.models import person
from fhirclient.models.fhirdate import FHIRDate
from fhirclient.models.fhirdatetime import FHIRDateTime
from fhirclient.models.fhirinstant import FHIRInstant
from fhirclient.models.fhirtime import FHIRTime


class PersonTests(unittest.TestCase):
    def instantiate_from(self, filename):
        datadir = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), '..', 'data', 'examples')
        with io.open(os.path.join(datadir, filename), 'r', encoding='utf-8') as handle:
            js = json.load(handle)
            self.assertEqual("Person", js["resourceType"])
        return person.Person(js)
    
    def testPerson1(self):
        inst = self.instantiate_from("person-example-f002-ariadne.json")
        self.assertIsNotNone(inst, "Must have instantiated a Person instance")
        self.implPerson1(inst)
        
        js = inst.as_json()
        self.assertEqual("Person", js["resourceType"])
        inst2 = person.Person(js)
        self.implPerson1(inst2)
    
    def implPerson1(self, inst):
        self.assertTrue(inst.active)
        self.assertEqual(inst.birthDate.date, FHIRDate("1963").date)
        self.assertEqual(inst.birthDate.as_json(), "1963")
        self.assertEqual(inst.gender, "female")
        self.assertEqual(inst.id, "f002")
        self.assertEqual(inst.meta.tag[0].code, "HTEST")
        self.assertEqual(inst.meta.tag[0].display, "test health data")
        self.assertEqual(inst.meta.tag[0].system, "http://terminology.hl7.org/CodeSystem/v3-ActReason")
        self.assertEqual(inst.name[0].text, "Ariadne Bor-Jansma")
        self.assertEqual(inst.name[0].use, "usual")
        self.assertEqual(inst.photo.contentType, "image/jpeg")
        self.assertEqual(inst.telecom[0].system, "phone")
        self.assertEqual(inst.telecom[0].use, "home")
        self.assertEqual(inst.telecom[0].value, "+31201234567")
        self.assertEqual(inst.text.status, "generated")
    
    def testPerson2(self):
        inst = self.instantiate_from("person-example.json")
        self.assertIsNotNone(inst, "Must have instantiated a Person instance")
        self.implPerson2(inst)
        
        js = inst.as_json()
        self.assertEqual("Person", js["resourceType"])
        inst2 = person.Person(js)
        self.implPerson2(inst2)
    
    def implPerson2(self, inst):
        self.assertTrue(inst.active)
        self.assertEqual(inst.address[0].city, "PleasantVille")
        self.assertEqual(inst.address[0].line[0], "534 Erewhon St")
        self.assertEqual(inst.address[0].postalCode, "3999")
        self.assertEqual(inst.address[0].state, "Vic")
        self.assertEqual(inst.address[0].use, "home")
        self.assertEqual(inst.birthDate.date, FHIRDate("1974-12-25").date)
        self.assertEqual(inst.birthDate.as_json(), "1974-12-25")
        self.assertEqual(inst.gender, "male")
        self.assertEqual(inst.id, "example")
        self.assertEqual(inst.identifier[0].period.start.datetime, FHIRDateTime("2001-05-06").datetime)
        self.assertEqual(inst.identifier[0].period.start.as_json(), "2001-05-06")
        self.assertEqual(inst.identifier[0].system, "urn:oid:1.2.36.146.595.217.0.1")
        self.assertEqual(inst.identifier[0].type.coding[0].code, "MR")
        self.assertEqual(inst.identifier[0].type.coding[0].system, "http://terminology.hl7.org/CodeSystem/v2-0203")
        self.assertEqual(inst.identifier[0].use, "usual")
        self.assertEqual(inst.identifier[0].value, "12345")
        self.assertEqual(inst.meta.tag[0].code, "HTEST")
        self.assertEqual(inst.meta.tag[0].display, "test health data")
        self.assertEqual(inst.meta.tag[0].system, "http://terminology.hl7.org/CodeSystem/v3-ActReason")
        self.assertEqual(inst.name[0].family, "Chalmers")
        self.assertEqual(inst.name[0].given[0], "Peter")
        self.assertEqual(inst.name[0].given[1], "James")
        self.assertEqual(inst.name[0].use, "official")
        self.assertEqual(inst.name[1].given[0], "Jim")
        self.assertEqual(inst.name[1].use, "usual")
        self.assertEqual(inst.telecom[0].use, "home")
        self.assertEqual(inst.telecom[1].system, "phone")
        self.assertEqual(inst.telecom[1].use, "work")
        self.assertEqual(inst.telecom[1].value, "(03) 5555 6473")
        self.assertEqual(inst.telecom[2].system, "email")
        self.assertEqual(inst.telecom[2].use, "home")
        self.assertEqual(inst.telecom[2].value, "Jim@example.org")
        self.assertEqual(inst.text.status, "generated")

# Generated from FHIR 4.0.1-9346c8cc45 (http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/DomainResource).
# 2024, SMART Health IT.


from . import resource

class DomainResource(resource.Resource):
    """ A resource with narrative, extensions, and contained resources.
    
    A resource that includes narrative, extensions, and contained resources.
    """
    
    resource_type = "DomainResource"
    
    def __init__(self, jsondict=None, strict=True):
        """ Initialize all valid properties.
        
        :raises: FHIRValidationError on validation errors, unless strict is False
        :param dict jsondict: A JSON dictionary to use for initialization
        :param bool strict: If True (the default), invalid variables will raise a TypeError
        """
        
        self.contained = None
        """ Contained, inline Resources.
        List of `Resource` items (represented as `dict` in JSON). """
        
        self.extension = None
        """ Additional content defined by implementations.
        List of `Extension` items (represented as `dict` in JSON). """
        
        self.modifierExtension = None
        """ Extensions that cannot be ignored.
        List of `Extension` items (represented as `dict` in JSON). """
        
        self.text = None
        """ Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation.
        Type `Narrative` (represented as `dict` in JSON). """
        
        super(DomainResource, self).__init__(jsondict=jsondict, strict=strict)
    
    def elementProperties(self):
        js = super(DomainResource, self).elementProperties()
        js.extend([
            ("contained", "contained", resource.Resource, True, None, False),
            ("extension", "extension", extension.Extension, True, None, False),
            ("modifierExtension", "modifierExtension", extension.Extension, True, None, False),
            ("text", "text", narrative.Narrative, False, None, False),
        ])
        return js

"""Facilitate working with FHIR time fields."""
# 2024, SMART Health IT.

import datetime
import re
from typing import Any, Union

from .fhirdate import FHIRDate


# This inherits from FHIRDate as a matter of backwards compatibility.
# (in case anyone was doing isinstance(obj, FHIRDate))
# Next time we bump the major version, we can stop that and also drop the
# backwards-compatible 'date' alias. R4-QUIRK

class FHIRDateTime(FHIRDate):
    """
    A convenience class for working with FHIR datetimes in Python.

    http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/datatypes.html#datetime

    Converting to a Python representation does require some compromises:
    - This class will convert partial dates ("reduced precision dates") like "2024" into full
      naive datetimes using the earliest possible time (in this example, "2024-01-01T00:00:00")
      because Python's datetime class does not support partial dates.
    - FHIR allows arbitrary sub-second precision, but Python only holds microseconds.
    - Leap seconds (:60) will be changed to the 59th second (:59) because Python's time classes
      do not support leap seconds.

    If such compromise is not useful for you, avoid using the `date`, `datetime`, or `isostring`
    properties and just use the `as_json()` method in order to work with the original,
    exact string.

    Public properties:
    - `datetime`: datetime.datetime representing the JSON value (naive or aware)
    - `date`: backwards-compatibility alias for `datetime`
    - `isostring`: an ISO 8601 string version of the above Python object

    Public methods:
    - `as_json`: returns the original JSON used to construct the instance
    """

    def __init__(self, jsonval: Union[str, None] = None):
        self.datetime: Union[datetime.datetime, None] = None
        super().__init__(jsonval)

    ##################################
    # Private properties and methods #
    ##################################

    # Pulled from spec for datetime
    _REGEX = re.compile(r"([0-9]([0-9]([0-9][1-9]|[1-9]0)|[1-9]00)|[1-9]000)(-(0[1-9]|1[0-2])(-(0[1-9]|[1-2][0-9]|3[0-1])(T([01][0-9]|2[0-3]):[0-5][0-9]:([0-5][0-9]|60)(\.[0-9]+)?(Z|(\+|-)((0[0-9]|1[0-3]):[0-5][0-9]|14:00)))?)?)?")
    _FIELD = "datetime"

    @staticmethod
    def _from_string(value: str) -> Any:
        return FHIRDate._parse_datetime(value)

# Generated from FHIR 4.0.1-9346c8cc45 (http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/Person).
# 2024, SMART Health IT.


from . import domainresource

class Person(domainresource.DomainResource):
    """ A generic person record.
    
    Demographics and administrative information about a person independent of a
    specific health-related context.
    """
    
    resource_type = "Person"
    
    def __init__(self, jsondict=None, strict=True):
        """ Initialize all valid properties.
        
        :raises: FHIRValidationError on validation errors, unless strict is False
        :param dict jsondict: A JSON dictionary to use for initialization
        :param bool strict: If True (the default), invalid variables will raise a TypeError
        """
        
        self.active = None
        """ This person's record is in active use.
        Type `bool`. """
        
        self.address = None
        """ One or more addresses for the person.
        List of `Address` items (represented as `dict` in JSON). """
        
        self.birthDate = None
        """ The date on which the person was born.
        Type `FHIRDate` (represented as `str` in JSON). """
        
        self.gender = None
        """ male | female | other | unknown.
        Type `str`. """
        
        self.identifier = None
        """ A human identifier for this person.
        List of `Identifier` items (represented as `dict` in JSON). """
        
        self.link = None
        """ Link to a resource that concerns the same actual person.
        List of `PersonLink` items (represented as `dict` in JSON). """
        
        self.managingOrganization = None
        """ The organization that is the custodian of the person record.
        Type `FHIRReference` (represented as `dict` in JSON). """
        
        self.name = None
        """ A name associated with the person.
        List of `HumanName` items (represented as `dict` in JSON). """
        
        self.photo = None
        """ Image of the person.
        Type `Attachment` (represented as `dict` in JSON). """
        
        self.telecom = None
        """ A contact detail for the person.
        List of `ContactPoint` items (represented as `dict` in JSON). """
        
        super(Person, self).__init__(jsondict=jsondict, strict=strict)
    
    def elementProperties(self):
        js = super(Person, self).elementProperties()
        js.extend([
            ("active", "active", bool, False, None, False),
            ("address", "address", address.Address, True, None, False),
            ("birthDate", "birthDate", fhirdate.FHIRDate, False, None, False),
            ("gender", "gender", str, False, None, False),
            ("identifier", "identifier", identifier.Identifier, True, None, False),
            ("link", "link", PersonLink, True, None, False),
            ("managingOrganization", "managingOrganization", fhirreference.FHIRReference, False, None, False),
            ("name", "name", humanname.HumanName, True, None, False),
            ("photo", "photo", attachment.Attachment, False, None, False),
            ("telecom", "telecom", contactpoint.ContactPoint, True, None, False),
        ])
        return js


from . import backboneelement

class PersonLink(backboneelement.BackboneElement):
    """ Link to a resource that concerns the same actual person.
    """
    
    resource_type = "PersonLink"
    
    def __init__(self, jsondict=None, strict=True):
        """ Initialize all valid properties.
        
        :raises: FHIRValidationError on validation errors, unless strict is False
        :param dict jsondict: A JSON dictionary to use for initialization
        :param bool strict: If True (the default), invalid variables will raise a TypeError
        """
        
        self.assurance = None
        """ level1 | level2 | level3 | level4.
        Type `str`. """
        
        self.target = None
        """ The resource to which this actual person is associated.
        Type `FHIRReference` (represented as `dict` in JSON). """
        
        super(PersonLink, self).__init__(jsondict=jsondict, strict=strict)
    
    def elementProperties(self):
        js = super(PersonLink, self).elementProperties()
        js.extend([
            ("assurance", "assurance", str, False, None, False),
            ("target", "target", fhirreference.FHIRReference, False, None, True),
        ])
        return js

def __init__(self, jsondict=None, strict=True):
        """Initialize a DomainResource object, which represents a FHIR resource with narrative, extensions, and contained resources.

Parameters:
- jsondict (dict, optional): A JSON dictionary used for initializing the resource properties. If provided, it should conform to the structure defined by FHIR.
- strict (bool, optional): If set to True (default), will raise a FHIRValidationError for any invalid properties during initialization.

Attributes:
- contained: A list of contained, inline resources (as dictionaries) associated with this DomainResource.
- extension: A list of additional content defined by implementations (as dictionaries).
- modifierExtension: A list of non-ignorable extensions (as dictionaries).
- text: A text summary of the resource for human interpretation, represented as a Narrative object.

This constructor calls the superclass's (`resource.Resource`) initializer to ensure that common resource properties are also initialized correctly."""
        ' Initialize all valid properties.\n        \n        :raises: FHIRValidationError on validation errors, unless strict is False\n        :param dict jsondict: A JSON dictionary to use for initialization\n        :param bool strict: If True (the default), invalid variables will raise a TypeError\n        '
        self.contained = None
        ' Contained, inline Resources.\n        List of `Resource` items (represented as `dict` in JSON). '
        self.extension = None
        ' Additional content defined by implementations.\n        List of `Extension` items (represented as `dict` in JSON). '
        self.modifierExtension = None
        ' Extensions that cannot be ignored.\n        List of `Extension` items (represented as `dict` in JSON). '
        self.text = None
        ' Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation.\n        Type `Narrative` (represented as `dict` in JSON). '
        super(DomainResource, self).__init__(jsondict=jsondict, strict=strict)

FHIRDate.__init__.code:
def __init__(self, jsonval: Union[str, None]=None):
        """Initializes a FHIRDate instance, facilitating the handling of FHIR date representations.

Parameters:
- jsonval (Union[str, None]): A string representing a FHIR date in ISO 8601 format. If provided, it must match the regular expression defined in `_REGEX`. If None, the date attribute will remain uninitialized.

Raises:
- TypeError: If jsonval is not a string.
- ValueError: If jsonval does not match the expected FHIR date format.

Attributes:
- date (Union[datetime.date, datetime.datetime, datetime.time, None]): Holds the parsed FHIR date representation in Python's datetime formats. It initializes to None if no valid jsonval is provided.
- origval (Union[str, None]): Stores the original JSON value used to create the instance, allowing for retrieval of the initial input.

Dependencies:
- The initialization relies on the constant `_REGEX`, which is a compiled regular expression that validates the format of the provided date string. The `_from_string` method is used for parsing the date string into a Python date object."""
        self.date: Union[datetime.date, datetime.datetime, datetime.time, None] = None
        if jsonval is not None:
            if not isinstance(jsonval, str):
                raise TypeError('Expecting string when initializing {}, but got {}'.format(type(self), type(jsonval)))
            if not self._REGEX.fullmatch(jsonval):
                raise ValueError('does not match expected format')
            self.date = self._from_string(jsonval)
        self.origval: Union[str, None] = jsonval
FHIRDate.__init__.docstring:
Initializes a FHIRDate instance, facilitating the handling of FHIR date representations.

Parameters:
- jsonval (Union[str, None]): A string representing a FHIR date in ISO 8601 format. If provided, it must match the regular expression defined in `_REGEX`. If None, the date attribute will remain uninitialized.

Raises:
- TypeError: If jsonval is not a string.
- ValueError: If jsonval does not match the expected FHIR date format.

Attributes:
- date (Union[datetime.date, datetime.datetime, datetime.time, None]): Holds the parsed FHIR date representation in Python's datetime formats. It initializes to None if no valid jsonval is provided.
- origval (Union[str, None]): Stores the original JSON value used to create the instance, allowing for retrieval of the initial input.

Dependencies:
- The initialization relies on the constant `_REGEX`, which is a compiled regular expression that validates the format of the provided date string. The `_from_string` method is used for parsing the date string into a Python date object.

FHIRDate.__setattr__.code:
def __setattr__(self, prop, value):
        """Sets an attribute on the FHIRDate instance, handling special synchronization for the 'date' property.

Parameters:
- prop (str): The name of the attribute to set.
- value (Any): The value to assign to the attribute.

This method ensures that when the 'date' attribute (or its associated field defined by _FIELD) is set, the original value (origval) is cleared to maintain consistency. The 'date' and the value for _FIELD are kept synchronized through direct attribute setting using object.__setattr__.

Constants used:
- _FIELD (str): Represents the internal field name for storing the date value, defined as "date". It dictates the behavior of synchronization within this method."""
        if prop in {'date', self._FIELD}:
            self.origval = None
            object.__setattr__(self, self._FIELD, value)
            object.__setattr__(self, 'date', value)
        else:
            object.__setattr__(self, prop, value)

- value (Any): The value to assign to the attribute.

This method ensures that when the 'date' attribute (or its associated field defined by _FIELD) is set, the original value (origval) is cleared to maintain consistency. The 'date' and the value for _FIELD are kept synchronized through direct attribute setting using object.__setattr__.

FHIRDate.as_json.docstring: Returns the original JSON string used to initialize this FHIRDate instance. If the instance was created with a valid ISO 8601 string, that string is returned. If not, it falls back to the ISO string representation of the date, which is generated by the `isostring` property. This property interacts with the `date` attribute, which stores a Python date representation of the FHIR date and can be `None` if not initialized. The method handles scenarios where the original input value (stored in `origval`) might not be available, ensuring graceful degradation in output while maintaining FHIR compliance.

FHIRDate._from_string.code:
def _from_string(value: str) -> Any:
        """Convert a FHIR date string into a Python `datetime.date` object.

Parameters:
- value (str): A string representation of a FHIR date, which is validated against the regex pattern defined in the class. The format must conform to the expected FHIR date standards.

Returns:
- Any: A `datetime.date` object that represents the date extracted from the input string.

This method utilizes the `_parse_date` static method, which internally calls `_parse_partial` to handle both complete and partial date strings, ensuring proper creation of a `datetime.date` object even for reduced precision dates. The `_REGEX` constant is referenced during initialization to validate the format of the input date string, ensuring that only valid date formats are processed."""
        return FHIRDate._parse_date(value)
FHIRDate._from_string.docstring:
Convert a FHIR date string into a Python `datetime.date` object.

Parameters:
- value (str): A string representation of a FHIR date, which is validated against the regex pattern defined in the class. The format must conform to the expected FHIR date standards.

Returns:
- Any: A `datetime.date` object that represents the date extracted from the input string.

This method utilizes the `_parse_date` static method, which internally calls `_parse_partial` to handle both complete and partial date strings, ensuring proper creation of a `datetime.date` object even for reduced precision dates. The `_REGEX` constant is referenced during initialization to validate the format of the input date string, ensuring that only valid date formats are processed.

FHIRAbstractBase.as_json.docstring:
Serializes the instance to a JSON dictionary by inspecting properties defined in `elementProperties()`. It checks for required properties that are not None and validates the types of properties against expected types.

Returns a validated dictionary that can be JSON serialized. If any required properties are missing, or if properties have incorrect types, `FHIRValidationError` is raised with details about the discrepancies. The method utilizes the `elementProperties()` method to retrieve properties of the instance and their associated validation criteria.

No input parameters are required. The method operates on the instance's attributes and uses local variables `js` (to build the resulting JSON dictionary), `errs` (to collect any encountered errors), `found` (to track properties that were found and serialized), and `nonoptionals` (to note properties that require values). These local variables are initialized within the method and are used to manage the serialization process effectively.

FHIRAbstractResource.as_json.code:
def as_json(self):
        """Generate a JSON representation of the FHIRAbstractResource instance.

This method overrides the `as_json` method from the superclass `FHIRAbstractBase` to include the `resourceType` key in the resulting JSON dictionary. The value of `resourceType` is set to the class-level attribute `resource_type`, which indicates the specific type of FHIR resource represented.

:return: A dictionary containing the JSON representation of the resource, including the added `resourceType` key.
:raises: None."""
        js = super(FHIRAbstractResource, self).as_json()
        js['resourceType'] = self.resource_type
        return js

:return: A dictionary containing the JSON representation of the resource, including the added `resourceType` key.
:raises: None.

FHIRDateTime.__init__.code:
def __init__(self, jsonval: Union[str, None]=None):
        """Initialize a FHIRDateTime instance.

Parameters:
- jsonval (Union[str, None]): A string representation of a FHIR datetime to initialize the instance. Defaults to None.

This constructor initializes the `datetime` attribute to None and calls the parent class (FHIRDate) initializer with the provided jsonval. The `datetime` attribute will later hold a `datetime.datetime` object, which represents the parsed FHIR datetime value. If the jsonval is not provided, the instance is created without a specific datetime value.

Dependencies:
- Inherits from FHIRDate, which is expected to parse the jsonval in its own initializer, potentially affecting the behavior of this class.
- The underlying datetime handling relies on Python's `datetime` module for date and time representations."""
        self.datetime: Union[datetime.datetime, None] = None
        super().__init__(jsonval)

Person.__init__.code:
def __init__(self, jsondict=None, strict=True):
        """Initialize a Person record with demographic and administrative information.

This constructor initializes all valid properties of a Person object based on the provided JSON dictionary. It accepts a dictionary to set initial values for the instance attributes and checks for validation errors unless strict mode is disabled. The attributes include the person's active status, addresses, birth date, gender, identifiers, links to related resources, managing organization, associated names, photo, and contact details.

Parameters:
- jsondict (dict, optional): A JSON dictionary for initializing properties of the Person instance. Each key corresponds to an attribute of the class.
- strict (bool, optional): If True (default), raises a TypeError for invalid properties; if False, allows them.

Attributes:
- active (bool): Indicates if the person's record is active.
- address (list of Address): Stores one or more addresses for the person.
- birthDate (FHIRDate): Represents the person's date of birth.
- gender (str): Indicates the gender of the person (male, female, other, or unknown).
- identifier (list of Identifier): Holds human identifiers for the person.
- link (list of PersonLink): Links to resources concerning the same person.
- managingOrganization (FHIRReference): The organization responsible for the person record.
- name (list of HumanName): Holds names associated with the person.
- photo (Attachment): An image of the person.
- telecom (list of ContactPoint): Contains contact details for the person.

This initialization function relies on several classes from the FHIR framework, including Address, FHIRDate, Identifier, PersonLink, FHIRReference, HumanName, Attachment, and ContactPoint, which are imported at the beginning of the module."""
        ' Initialize all valid properties.\n        \n        :raises: FHIRValidationError on validation errors, unless strict is False\n        :param dict jsondict: A JSON dictionary to use for initialization\n        :param bool strict: If True (the default), invalid variables will raise a TypeError\n        '
        self.active = None
        " This person's record is in active use.\n        Type `bool`. "
        self.address = None
        ' One or more addresses for the person.\n        List of `Address` items (represented as `dict` in JSON). '
        self.birthDate = None
        ' The date on which the person was born.\n        Type `FHIRDate` (represented as `str` in JSON). '
        self.gender = None
        ' male | female | other | unknown.\n        Type `str`. '
        self.identifier = None
        ' A human identifier for this person.\n        List of `Identifier` items (represented as `dict` in JSON). '
        self.link = None
        ' Link to a resource that concerns the same actual person.\n        List of `PersonLink` items (represented as `dict` in JSON). '
        self.managingOrganization = None
        ' The organization that is the custodian of the person record.\n        Type `FHIRReference` (represented as `dict` in JSON). '
        self.name = None
        ' A name associated with the person.\n        List of `HumanName` items (represented as `dict` in JSON). '
        self.photo = None
        ' Image of the person.\n        Type `Attachment` (represented as `dict` in JSON). '
        self.telecom = None
        ' A contact detail for the person.\n        List of `ContactPoint` items (represented as `dict` in JSON). '
        super(Person, self).__init__(jsondict=jsondict, strict=strict)

Initialize a Person record with demographic and administrative information.

This constructor initializes all valid properties of a Person object based on the provided JSON dictionary. It accepts a dictionary to set initial values for the instance attributes and checks for validation errors unless strict mode is disabled. The attributes include the person's active status, addresses, birth date, gender, identifiers, links to related resources, managing organization, associated names, photo, and contact details.

Parameters:
- jsondict (dict, optional): A JSON dictionary for initializing properties of the Person instance. Each key corresponds to an attribute of the class.
- strict (bool, optional): If True (default), raises a TypeError for invalid properties; if False, allows them.

Attributes:
- active (bool): Indicates if the person's record is active.
- address (list of Address): Stores one or more addresses for the person.
- birthDate (FHIRDate): Represents the person's date of birth.
- gender (str): Indicates the gender of the person (male, female, other, or unknown).
- identifier (list of Identifier): Holds human identifiers for the person.
- link (list of PersonLink): Links to resources concerning the same person.
- managingOrganization (FHIRReference): The organization responsible for the person record.
- name (list of HumanName): Holds names associated with the person.
- photo (Attachment): An image of the person.
- telecom (list of ContactPoint): Contains contact details for the person.

This initialization function relies on several classes from the FHIR framework, including Address, FHIRDate, Identifier, PersonLink, FHIRReference, HumanName, Attachment, and ContactPoint, which are imported at the beginning of the module.

# IMPLEMENTATION REQUIREMENTS:
## MODULE DESCRIPTION:
The module facilitates the validation and manipulation of FHIR (Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources) `Person` resources in compliance with the FHIR 4.0.1 standard. It provides capabilities to instantiate, validate, and serialize `Person` resources, ensuring that all attributes such as demographic information, identifiers, contact details, and metadata conform to the FHIR specifications. By offering robust testing functionality, the module helps verify the integrity and accuracy of data within `Person` resources and supports seamless interaction with healthcare interoperability systems. This streamlines the development of FHIR-compliant applications by enabling developers to validate resource structure and content, reducing errors and simplifying data integration in healthcare environments.

```python
"""
Initialize a DomainResource object, which represents a FHIR resource with narrative, extensions, and contained resources.

Parameters:
- jsondict (dict, optional): A JSON dictionary used for initializing the resource properties. If provided, it should conform to the structure defined by FHIR.
- strict (bool, optional): If set to True (default), will raise a FHIRValidationError for any invalid properties during initialization.

Attributes:
- contained: A list of contained, inline resources (as dictionaries) associated with this DomainResource.
- extension: A list of additional content defined by implementations (as dictionaries).
- modifierExtension: A list of non-ignorable extensions (as dictionaries).
- text: A text summary of the resource for human interpretation, represented as a Narrative object.

This constructor calls the superclass's (`resource.Resource`) initializer to ensure that common resource properties are also initialized correctly.
"""
```

## FILE 2: fhirclient/models/fhirdate.py

- CLASS METHOD: FHIRDate.__init__
  - CLASS SIGNATURE: class FHIRDate:
  - SIGNATURE: def __init__(self, jsonval: Union[str, None]=None):
  - DOCSTRING: 
```python
"""
Initializes a FHIRDate instance, facilitating the handling of FHIR date representations.

Parameters:
- jsonval (Union[str, None]): A string representing a FHIR date in ISO 8601 format. If provided, it must match the regular expression defined in `_REGEX`. If None, the date attribute will remain uninitialized.

Raises:
- TypeError: If jsonval is not a string.
- ValueError: If jsonval does not match the expected FHIR date format.

Attributes:
- date (Union[datetime.date, datetime.datetime, datetime.time, None]): Holds the parsed FHIR date representation in Python's datetime formats. It initializes to None if no valid jsonval is provided.
- origval (Union[str, None]): Stores the original JSON value used to create the instance, allowing for retrieval of the initial input.

Dependencies:
- The initialization relies on the constant `_REGEX`, which is a compiled regular expression that validates the format of the provided date string. The `_from_string` method is used for parsing the date string into a Python date object.
"""
```

- CLASS METHOD: FHIRDate.as_json
  - CLASS SIGNATURE: class FHIRDate:
  - SIGNATURE: def as_json(self) -> Union[str, None]:
  - DOCSTRING: 
```python
"""
Returns the original JSON string used to initialize this FHIRDate instance. If the instance was created with a valid ISO 8601 string, that string is returned. If not, it falls back to the ISO string representation of the date, which is generated by the `isostring` property. This property interacts with the `date` attribute, which stores a Python date representation of the FHIR date and can be `None` if not initialized. The method handles scenarios where the original input value (stored in `origval`) might not be available, ensuring graceful degradation in output while maintaining FHIR compliance.
"""
```

- CLASS METHOD: FHIRDate._from_string
  - CLASS SIGNATURE: class FHIRDate:
  - SIGNATURE: def _from_string(value: str) -> Any:
  - DOCSTRING: 
```python
"""
Convert a FHIR date string into a Python `datetime.date` object.

Parameters:
- value (str): A string representation of a FHIR date, which is validated against the regex pattern defined in the class. The format must conform to the expected FHIR date standards.

Returns:
- Any: A `datetime.date` object that represents the date extracted from the input string.

This method utilizes the `_parse_date` static method, which internally calls `_parse_partial` to handle both complete and partial date strings, ensuring proper creation of a `datetime.date` object even for reduced precision dates. The `_REGEX` constant is referenced during initialization to validate the format of the input date string, ensuring that only valid date formats are processed.
"""
```

- CLASS METHOD: FHIRDate.__setattr__
  - CLASS SIGNATURE: class FHIRDate:
  - SIGNATURE: def __setattr__(self, prop, value):
  - DOCSTRING: 
```python
"""
Sets an attribute on the FHIRDate instance, handling special synchronization for the 'date' property.

Parameters:
- prop (str): The name of the attribute to set.
- value (Any): The value to assign to the attribute.

This method ensures that when the 'date' attribute (or its associated field defined by _FIELD) is set, the original value (origval) is cleared to maintain consistency. The 'date' and the value for _FIELD are kept synchronized through direct attribute setting using object.__setattr__.

Constants used:
- _FIELD (str): Represents the internal field name for storing the date value, defined as "date". It dictates the behavior of synchronization within this method.
"""
```

## FILE 3: fhirclient/models/fhirabstractbase.py

- CLASS METHOD: FHIRAbstractBase.as_json
  - CLASS SIGNATURE: class FHIRAbstractBase(object):

  - DOCSTRING: 
```python
"""
Serializes the instance to a JSON dictionary by inspecting properties defined in `elementProperties()`. It checks for required properties that are not None and validates the types of properties against expected types.

Returns a validated dictionary that can be JSON serialized. If any required properties are missing, or if properties have incorrect types, `FHIRValidationError` is raised with details about the discrepancies. The method utilizes the `elementProperties()` method to retrieve properties of the instance and their associated validation criteria.

No input parameters are required. The method operates on the instance's attributes and uses local variables `js` (to build the resulting JSON dictionary), `errs` (to collect any encountered errors), `found` (to track properties that were found and serialized), and `nonoptionals` (to note properties that require values). These local variables are initialized within the method and are used to manage the serialization process effectively.
"""
```

If the jsonval is not provided, the instance is created without a specific datetime value.

Dependencies:

"""

from . import resource

class DomainResource(resource.Resource):
    """ A resource with narrative, extensions, and contained resources.
    
    A resource that includes narrative, extensions, and contained resources.
    """
    resource_type = 'DomainResource'

    def elementProperties(self):
        js = super(DomainResource, self).elementProperties()
        js.extend([('contained', 'contained', resource.Resource, True, None, False), ('extension', 'extension', extension.Extension, True, None, False), ('modifierExtension', 'modifierExtension', extension.Extension, True, None, False), ('text', 'text', narrative.Narrative, False, None, False)])
        return js
from . import extension
from . import narrative
file_code.fhirclient/models/fhirdatetime.py:
"""Facilitate working with FHIR time fields."""
import datetime
import re
from typing import Any, Union
from .fhirdate import FHIRDate

class FHIRDateTime(FHIRDate):
    """
    A convenience class for working with FHIR datetimes in Python.

    http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/datatypes.html#datetime

    Converting to a Python representation does require some compromises:
    - This class will convert partial dates ("reduced precision dates") like "2024" into full
      naive datetimes using the earliest possible time (in this example, "2024-01-01T00:00:00")
      because Python's datetime class does not support partial dates.
    - FHIR allows arbitrary sub-second precision, but Python only holds microseconds.
    - Leap seconds (:60) will be changed to the 59th second (:59) because Python's time classes
      do not support leap seconds.

    If such compromise is not useful for you, avoid using the `date`, `datetime`, or `isostring`
    properties and just use the `as_json()` method in order to work with the original,
    exact string.

    Public properties:
    - `datetime`: datetime.datetime representing the JSON value (naive or aware)
    - `date`: backwards-compatibility alias for `datetime`
    - `isostring`: an ISO 8601 string version of the above Python object

    Public methods:
    - `as_json`: returns the original JSON used to construct the instance
    """
    _REGEX = re.compile('([0-9]([0-9]([0-9][1-9]|[1-9]0)|[1-9]00)|[1-9]000)(-(0[1-9]|1[0-2])(-(0[1-9]|[1-2][0-9]|3[0-1])(T([01][0-9]|2[0-3]):[0-5][0-9]:([0-5][0-9]|60)(\\.[0-9]+)?(Z|(\\+|-)((0[0-9]|1[0-3]):[0-5][0-9]|14:00)))?)?)?')
    _FIELD = 'datetime'

    @staticmethod
    def _from_string(value: str) -> Any:
        return FHIRDate._parse_datetime(value)

from . import domainresource

class Person(domainresource.DomainResource):
    """ A generic person record.
    
    Demographics and administrative information about a person independent of a
    specific health-related context.
    """
    resource_type = 'Person'

    def elementProperties(self):
        js = super(Person, self).elementProperties()
        js.extend([('active', 'active', bool, False, None, False), ('address', 'address', address.Address, True, None, False), ('birthDate', 'birthDate', fhirdate.FHIRDate, False, None, False), ('gender', 'gender', str, False, None, False), ('identifier', 'identifier', identifier.Identifier, True, None, False), ('link', 'link', PersonLink, True, None, False), ('managingOrganization', 'managingOrganization', fhirreference.FHIRReference, False, None, False), ('name', 'name', humanname.HumanName, True, None, False), ('photo', 'photo', attachment.Attachment, False, None, False), ('telecom', 'telecom', contactpoint.ContactPoint, True, None, False)])
        return js
from . import backboneelement

class PersonLink(backboneelement.BackboneElement):
    """ Link to a resource that concerns the same actual person.
    """
    resource_type = 'PersonLink'

    def __init__(self, jsondict=None, strict=True):
        """ Initialize all valid properties.
        
        :raises: FHIRValidationError on validation errors, unless strict is False
        :param dict jsondict: A JSON dictionary to use for initialization
        :param bool strict: If True (the default), invalid variables will raise a TypeError
        """
        self.assurance = None
        ' level1 | level2 | level3 | level4.\n        Type `str`. '
        self.target = None
        ' The resource to which this actual person is associated.\n        Type `FHIRReference` (represented as `dict` in JSON). '
        super(PersonLink, self).__init__(jsondict=jsondict, strict=strict)

    def elementProperties(self):
        js = super(PersonLink, self).elementProperties()
        js.extend([('assurance', 'assurance', str, False, None, False), ('target', 'target', fhirreference.FHIRReference, False, None, True)])
        return js
